data.title: Country music artist Ronnie McDowell to headline Ripley Fourth of July Celebration
data.meta_description: West Virginians will get a taste of Nashville this summer as country music star Ronnie McDowell is slated bring his songs to Ripley’s Independence Day celebrati
data.text:
West Virginians will get a taste of Nashville this summer as is slated bring his songs to Ripley’s Independence Day celebration.

McDowell is scheduled to take the stage on June 30 as part of the Ripley Fourth of July Celebration, according to a news release from the city.

The news release said McDowell has appeared on the Grand Ole Opry and performed with the likes of Conway Twitter, Tammy Wynette and Loretta Lynn.

McDowell rose to fame in the late 1970s after releasing the hit “The King is Gone” as a reaction to the death of Elvis Presley. McDowell has made appearances in movies and television and created 30 top ten records.

“When a friend appeached me about the possibility of bringing such a big superstar to Ripley, I didn’t think we could afford it,” Ripley Mayor Carolyn Rader stated in a news release. “Through the generous support of our sponsors, we were able to make it happen.”

The artist’s latest studio effort entitled “Ronnie McDowell County” is in the works and will contain a collection of six new songs.

Ripley’s Fourth of July Celebration dates back to the late 1800’s and is the oldest Independence Day celebration in the state. This year’s event is scheduled to stretch from Thursday, June 29 to Tuesday, July 4.

Additional information, including a full schedule of events is .
